thread.title: Supermarket raises pay above national living wage but there's a catch - Leicester Mercury

author: Simon Smith
title: Supermarket raises pay above national living wage but there's a catch - Leicester Mercury
text:
Supermarket raises pay above national living wage but there's a catch Sainsbury's is giving 130,000 workers new contracts Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get Daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! The lowest paid workers at Sainsbury's are to see their pay packets increase to levels above the national living wage. 
It is raising the basic rate of pay from £8 to £9.20 an hour across the country and to £9.80 an hour in London. 
The sting in the tail is that it is scrapping its spring bonus and is putting a stop to paid breaks. 
New contracts have been introduced for 130,000 members of staff in an attempt to ensure fairness, regardless of age or length of service, reports the Manchester Evening News . 
The pay rise will be funded by cost savings within the business, the supermarket has said. It says that it will be investing £100 million in its employees this year. 
With new contracts, the company is aiming ensure "consistency and fairness" across all its stores, regardless of age or length of service. Read More 
The number of roles will be cut from 22 to five - trading assistant, food services assistant, online assistant, general merchandise and clothing assistant, and services assistant. 
A bonus usually paid in the spring will end, as will paid breaks. 
Sainsbury's said a small number of staff may be adversely affected, adding that top-up payments will be made for 18 months to ensure no-one earns less than they do today. 
Consultations with staff have started and the new pay rate is planned to start in September. Read More Here's how to bag all 10 live Sky Sports channels at a MASSIVE discount 
Sainsbury's retail and operations director Simon Roberts said: "The retail sector has never been more competitive and we know that our customers really value our colleagues and the excellent service they provide in our shops. 
"Which is why we think it is so important to invest further in our colleagues so they feel rewarded and motivated to do the best possible job for our customers every day. 
"We expect the best from our teams and that's why we're committing to a leading rate of pay. Great pay for great work. Read More Melton Mowbray pork pies, Leicestershire cheese and Rutland beer under threat if US gets its way post-Brexit 
"Together with our recent proposals to change our management structure in stores, we believe the proposed changes will set us up to run the best shops in the industry, delivering the best possible service for our customers." 
Joanne McGuinness, national officer of the shopworkers' union Usdaw, said: "Usdaw has long been making the case for the real living wage and beyond, so this deal takes Sainsbury's staff 45p per hour above that £8.75 rate. 
"While this is welcome news for Usdaw members working in Sainsbury's, we will be looking closely at the whole deal, as we understand the company are proposing some contractual changes. Read More More snow for Leicester as fresh weather warning is issued 
"Consolidating pay can benefit staff, but we want to check the effects on all individual workers." 
The national living wage is £7.50 an hour for over 25-year-olds, while the voluntary "real" figure is £8.75, and £10.20 in London. Like us on Facebook
